Even before the Moon reaches the Roche Limit, it would, in its own right, start experiencing volcanism! This is because all the tidal kneading on the Moon would exert enough friction to heat the Moon's interior to the point of melting. This is the reason why the Jovian moon Io has active volcanoes.

Good thing the Yuuzhan Vong DON'T exist! You see, one of that "Star Wars Expanded Universe" race's many bio-devices is something called a dovin basal, which is capable of exerting gravity on anything -- including an orbiting moon. Indeed, crashing moons into their host planets is one of the Yuuzhan Vong's war maneuvers; it's called Yo'Gand's Core. A dovin basal aimed at a moon causes said moon to spiral in toward the victim planet, eventually crashing into it.

Now for a part two.

Let us entertain the plot of "Despicable Me".

Gru develops a means to supernaturally compress and steal the moon. The moon, following the movie's timeline, is gone for a day or two.

As Gru's rocketry can make the three day travel in hours, Gru successfully returns the moon to its stable orbit before it returns to its full size.

What happens to the tides during that period? How is the earth affected before Gru puts it back?

I love how you approached this as if the moon's orbit, which is always spiraling anyway, slowed. I was hoping to learn what would happen if the moon directly crashed within a few months like in video games, but this was WAY more entertaining.
I love this channel. So much work goes into it just to keep us informed. Thank you so much!

You overlooked one major effect.   The inside of the Moon is very hot.   Not like the Earth's, but estimated 1,300 - 1,470 C, according to a study.    That's, about 2,400 to 2,600 degrees F.  That's hot.   Hot enough to glow red.    So as the moon breaks apart, we'd have this red-glowing ring that would quickly radiate heat away and cool off, but not quickly enough.   That would warm the Earth several degrees, maybe a few tens of degrees for a brief period.    It would be quite something to see, but could also be enough to melt much of the ice over Antarctica.

Much of this happened in reverse, albeit over billions of years.

First with the impact of Theia, which resulted in a massive ring system made from the ejecta (which is why moon rocks are nearly isotopicially identical to Earth rocks).

After millions of years, much of the rings coalesced into the proto-Luna, which would have been molten, radiating heat & light, criss-crossed with volcanoes spewing smoke & gasses. It would have been nightmarishly close, perhaps 6-8 times bigger in the sky & causing massive 50m high tides.

Now, some 4.5 Billion years later, it's receeded by thousands of metres. cooled to the point of barely a few Kelvin, outside of direct sunlight where it can reach hundreds.
The surface is spattered with craters, most from the late, heavy bombardment, as there's no tectonic activity or weather erosion to erase them.

In 2009 there was a two part movie made for television that aired called Impact. The plot featured the moon being struck by a large asteroid made from extremely dense material which caused it to slowly start 'falling' to earth.

In it there was a scene where some kids were playing baseball and the proximity of the moon caused a pop fly to soar many times higher and further than it normally would have. I can't help but imagine this was the inspiration for some of the graphics in this video.

It should also be noted that after the fact this show was intensely mocked by the scientific community for it's total ignoring of how orbits actually work. With one commentator going as far as to say: "After I watched this I hope the moon does hit the earth."

majora's mask moon in a nutshell

It seems like there is a need to clarify something. First off, since we already established that we can use "magic" to manipulate the moon's orbit in the video, then we can safely say that we can just use "magic" to completely kill off the moon's orbital velocity and it will fall in a straight line towards the earth. That would be the predicted cosmic catastrophe that happens when the moon actually crashes into the earth. In the video however, the sort of magic used to destabilize the moon's orbit can be summarized as gradually decreasing the moon's orbital velocity thereby reducing the moon's orbital radius. This causes the moon to hit the Roche limit as per what the video reveals.

Both of these scenarios do not necessarily break the laws of physics theoretically, as long as you have the massive amount of energy required to stop the moon from orbiting at all. The only difference is the time it takes to input that said energy. The scenario where the moon straight crashes into earth means that the energy was spent near instantaneously to stop the moon while the scenario shown in the video requires the energy to be inputted over the span of a year. Either way, both scenarios are completely plausible.

The title of the video is misleading in that it asks for what happens in one case but goes and explains an outcome for a different case altogether, even though both cases have completely different but equally interesting results.

Personally I would like to see another video of what ACTUALLY happens when the moon crashes into the Earth, just for the sake of correction.

Source: I play Kerbal Space Program and Universe Simulator. Also studied Orbital Mechanics back in Uni.

Mariupol. Bevor diesem Winter war die Stadt sicher, gemütlich und florierend. Bevor diesem Winter lachte Ortsansässigen, klangen Meer und Seemöwe. Bevor dem Krieg lebten die Menschen hier. Aber bei russischem Angriff ist alles in einem Moment zusammengebrochen.
Am 9. März bombardierten russische Okkupationstruppen Kinderkrankenhaus und Entbindungsheim in Mariupol absichtlich. Wegen des Beschusses starben 3 Menschen, es gab 17 Verletzten. Eine schwangere Frau mit ihrem ungeborenen Kind überlebten nicht.
Nicht nur Krankenhäuser und Entbindungsheime sondern auch Schulen, Kindergarten und Kulturgebäude sind Ziele für russische Anschläge. Am 16. März warfen die russischen Soldaten eine Superbombe auf Schauspielhaus im Stadtzentrum, wo hunderte Menschen sich zum Zeitpunkt des Anschlags befanden. Am 19. März litt eine Kunstschule, in der sich rund 400 Menschen, darunter Kinder, Frauen und ältere Leute, befanden, an einer Beschießung.
Ungefähr 20 tausend Zivilisten sind in Mariupol während der russischen Blockade gestorben.
Allerdings hören Okkupationstruppe mit Beschuss und ständigem Terror nicht auf. Mariupols Einwohner werden in Filtrationslager geschickt, wo sie ihre Handys und Dokumente abgeben müssen. Später erhalten einige der Deportieren Besatzungsausweise und werden in abgelegene Städte Russlands geschickt. Dieser Schritt ähnelt sich Sowjetischen Deportationsoperationen.
Nach allen Tatsachen und Zahlen entsteht eine Frage: Kämpfen russische Truppen gegen schwangere Frauen, künftige geborene Kinder oder Senioren? Ich kann kaum eine andere Antwort, die verschieden von der ist, finden: Das ist blanker Terror und zielbewusstes Genozid der Ukrainer.

After an unknown number of years, human beings have spread all over the earth again, dynasties have changed, and royal power has been established and collapsed. In every quiet evening, between the sighs of the elderly and the laughter of children, there is a legend circulating. In the distant past, there was a glorious and great magical era, when human beings did not live under the mountains and walk in the dim light, but in the huge cities on the ground. Everyone can be equally bathed in the divine sunshine, and there is no need to worry that their residence is too far away from the sunshine. People even argue about which time the sun is greater at noon or in the evening. What's even more amazing is that in that era, there were no magnificent silver arches in the sky, but a disc of white brilliance hung in the distant sky. On every clear night, when people looked up, they could see. to it. Later, the people on the ground were no longer satisfied with watching the disc from a distance, they wanted to get closer to it, so they decided to pull it over and made great efforts for it. Although the human beings in that magical age had powers far beyond the present, it was still extremely difficult, but in the end, the effort paid off, and the disk began to approach the earth little by little. But unfortunately, this effort eventually led to a terrible disaster. The gods were angry with humans for trying to get their hands on the white and flawless disk, so the sea swelled, flooded the land, made volcanoes erupt, covered the sky, made the earth tremble and tear shattered the city. In the midst of this chaos, the Age of Magic came to an abrupt end, and with the exception of our most fortunate ancestors, the vast majority of human beings were killed, and even the disc was taken away, and humanity could no longer see its splendor. But the disc was pitiful, and it tore off a part of itself and made a silver arch that stood above the sky, as evidence of that magical age, and an eternal epitaph.

Hey Chief, the moon has been moving AWAY from Earth at a rate as small as 1cm to as much as 1meter per year. They've been measuring it with a Laser since the Apollo missions. The reason is, the Moon gets bombarded with meteorites, holds on to most of them and keeps gaining more and more mass. Most Earth meteors skip across and back out into space or get burned up in our atmosphere.

Sadly because of these Mis-Info Cartooneys and even sadder, fictional text books. Most people don't know and can't picture in their heads, just how far the Moon actually is from Earth nor what the Earth and the Moon would actually look like in the same photo. They are so far apart (avg of 30 Earth diameters), that if you were to try and illustrate it on a standard sheet of printer-paper (turned landscape) and you started by drawing the Earth as a small 10mm diameter circle at one end, your paper still wouldn't be long enough to add your tiny 2.5mm Moon. Since I've already drawn it so many times, take your paper and draw an 8mm circle (Earth) in the top left corner, then draw a 2mm circle (Moon) in the lower right corner and there it is your accurate illustration of an Earth-Moon selfie.

Now using a basketball or beachball to illustrate the Sun, figure to scale how far each of our planets are from the Beachball. (hint) Pluto to scale would be about the size of a tiny grain of sand and would still take you weeks to walk to it. 😆😂🤣

5:47 -- "...combined with the weight of quintillions of tons of water..."
For some perspective on these truly unfathomable numbers,
One billion seconds is 31 years.
One trillion seconds is 31,000 years.
1 quintillion seconds is 31.6 billion years.
One quintillion tons is 62 sextillion pounds.
One sextillion seconds is over 31 trillion years.
So 62 sextillion seconds is 372 quadrillion years.

Un... real.
The kicker being that these numbers are actually VERY small compared to others. Infinity itself is all but impossible to truly and fully comprehend -- other than "It's forever."
You could write a 10 followed by zeroes as fast as you can for the rest of your life and never come even REMOTELY close to infinity.

Ehh, realistically, pretty much as soon as the moon starts breaking apart, you have a few hours before massive meteor showers so numerous that they'd boil the majority of the oceans off the planet, displacing the atmosphere and at a temperature approaching that of the surface of the sun. It wouldn't even take much of the Moon's mass to do this, less than a quarter of it falling in, when more than half of it would based on its prior trajectory.

Unless somebody had supplies to survive miles underground for at least a couple of hundred years, no humans would survive.

Edit, worse, any survivors would have no tide at all, meaning the seas would be permanently dead. No fish, most sea life either gone or clustered around deep geothermals. The oceans would become increasingly toxic without the mitigating actions of countless micro-organisms processing inflowing materials. Most oxygen is also produced by plankton and such, so the atmosphere would not be regenerating quickly.

So, nothing survives on the surface land, nothing survives in the oceans except perhaps some deep geothermal-dwelling organisms, and even they would be at risk from the higher temperatures and altered water chemistry.

Now how about a video showing what happens once we lose the moon. Rather than gravity pulling the moon down, gravity is actually accelerating the moon farther out each year. The Moon continues to spin away from the Earth, at the rate of 3.78cm (1.48in) per year because that tidal bulge you depicted as being directly below the moon is actually slightly ahead of the moon due to earth's rotation being much faster than the moon's relative orbital speed. The moon's gravity is pulling back on that bulge, slowing earth's rotation down, but gravity from that bulge is also pulling the moon forward at an ever increasing speed, causing it to spiral away from us. What happens once the moon's gravity can no longer keep earth from wobbling on it axis?

Would it be theoretically possible for a moon-sized object to enter the solar system and collide with our moon in the direction opposite its motion, slowing it down and causing this sequence of events? At any rate, I feel like this would make an extraordinarily good movie.

In reality the moon is actually getting further and further away at the rate of 3.78cm (1.48in) per year, (at about the same speed at which our fingernails grow) If the earth is not destroyed by the red phase of the sun, it will leave the gravitational pull of the planet and spiral away in around 15 billion years..... When it was first formed from a planetoid collision with the earth around 4 billion years ago, the moon orbited at around 22,500 kilometers (14,000 miles ) and its massive gravitational effects for billions of years was pivotal to how earth and life developed.

The moon will eventually be captured by Earth's gravity.  The Earth's stronger gravity is slowing down the moon's 27 day cycle.  Once it reaches 47 days, the moon will be locked into whichever hemisphere it is facing, and it will forever be seen only in this hemisphere.  At this point, the moon will begin the slow inward path towards the Earth.  Once the moon is within 11,000 miles, or roughly 17,500km, it will cause a terminal breakup of the moon.  It will either become rings around Earth, or be entirely claimed by our planet.  I am hoping for rings, personally.

Can you explain how the moon is evenly lit across its surface when all other spheres that reflect light have hot spots at the closest point to the light source?

To clarify, all spheres reflecting light have a point of intensity and the light fades around the curve of the sphere. The moon does not operate this way. Why not?

This is easily proven by any light source and any shiny ball.
Instead, the moon is a dust covered rock and, yet, it reflects light with such intensity as to allow one to read a book.

On that same line of thinking; how bright is the moon if we can see it reflecting light from 500,000 miles? The light of the sun must travel 250,000 past us, bounce, and return another 250,000 miles. Using the Inverse Square Law, how much more light must hit the moon at night vs the day when the moon visible during the day vs being visible at night?

It would be interesting to write a short story about this scenario.  It takes place a couple of months into the process, where the moon has spiraled toward the earth for sixty days and news of the coming moonfall has permeated our entire global population.  The tides are rising high enough to flood the coastal cities every day.  High tide eventually make skyscrapers look like the fingers of a drowning person reaching for heaven in hope and futility.  The portion of the population who see that the end is inevitable and don't want to suffer the death of the planet have voluntarily ended their own lives.  The only ones who survive are those who have decided to live until the very end, no matter what happens.  It is not a majority of the population, but there are many who choose to tough it out to the very end.  They exist in small groups, scattered throughout the world, scavenging supplies from a dead transportation system and from the houses of the deceased, while they use whatever technology they can fond in order to resist the damage of the dying of The Earth, as the moon sinks closer and closer in the sky.  The story finally focuses on one specific group with characters that we grow to care about, as their lives become increasingly dangerous and bizarre, battling hundred meter tsunamis every day, as the oceans take over the world and then recede past the horizon revealing a vast landscape that remained hidden beneath the water for billions of years. Volcanos erupt, massive earthquakes throttle the land, and eventually the gravitational friction generated by the moons unnatural proximity slowly shatters the surface of the very planet.  In their last moments, our group witnesses as the horizon itself breaks apart, continents rise into the sky and then burst into molten lava as hell rains both up and down, the air broils alive anything that was still alive, until the grand joining renders and incinerates all in unimaginable brilliance into a deafening solid white all.

The thumbnail is a bit inaccurate though. If the Moon stopped revolving around the Earth completely, it would fall down straight towards the Earth's center. It might disintegrate in the process (since gravity is inversely proportional to distance, and hence the parts closer to the Earth would accelerate faster than those on the other side) but not necessarily, given that the edge hitting the Earth would decelerate due to air drag. So it is entirely possible that it would hit the Earth intact, like a massive asteroid would.

In reality, the moon moves about a half inch FURTHER away from the Earth each year, due to it's outward orbital force.  The moon is currently 238.8K miles from the Earth. Since the end of the dinasaur era 60M years ago, it has travelled approximately 30M inches. At 63.3K inches per mile, that means the Earth is 473 miles further away from the Earth than it was 60M years ago. Eventually, in the distant future, the moon will break free from Earth's gravitational pull and float freely in space until it gets pulled in by another body's gravitational pull. The only way the moon could ever crash into the Earth is if a yet-undiscovered comet impacts the moon at the perfect angle as to redirect it's orbit to impact the planet. Basically a cosmic billiards game and we're the table pocket. Cute kindergarten graphics, though.

You forgot the Moon isn't solid rock.  It doesn't just "disintegrate," its metal core continues to fall onto the Earth, freed from the pressure exerted upon it by the Moon's mantle.  It accelerates to terminal velocity, briefly liquefying before cooling down enough to solidify once more into a much larger sphere about the size of New Jersey.  Earth's topography gives roughly a 70% chance to crash into an ocean basin, where the crust is thinnest.  It crashes through unabated and continues to sink down into Earth's mantle, causing an earthquake of unprecedented magnitude and either exacerbating the tidal situation with tsunamis or choking the atmosphere with volcanic ash, depending on where it hits.  Not that it matters because in mere minutes it will impact Earth's core and the resulting resonance in the mantle will shatter and capsize the tectonic plates, completely wiping out all surviving life on the planet.

Have you ever heard of Solon? It's a thought experiment proposed by Neil F. Comins in his book "What If the Moon Didn't Exist? Voyages to Earths That Might Have Been".
Basically, without the Moon's gravity influencing earth and it's tides, earth would spin much faster, creating permanent gales of 200+ km/h winds that scour the planet's surface. Anything that lives there is flat and well-anchored to the ground in order to avoid being blown away.
My question is, would the rings of lunar debris be enough to prevent this scenario?

One thing to consider is that without a moon, the apocalypse would continue anyway. Since the lunar tides would be gone completely, there would be massive tidal waves that shift in the direction of a solar tide. Plus, the moon keeps Earth’s axial tilt and rotation in check, so seasons would be far more dramatic than they are already and life on Earth would need to adapt to a dynamic day length. In addition, the moon has provided Earth protection against numerous impacts, so Earth would only be more vulnerable.

If the Moon fell into Earth, that would make the Chicxulub impactor that wiped out the dinosaurs seem like a tiny pebble hitting the ground in comparison. All life on Earth, and I mean all of it, would die. And not, not even the cockroaches would survive. In fact, not even bacteria would survive. Here is what would happen: the entire crust of the planet up to 100 miles deep would be instantly vaporized. The 500 miles beneath that would be turn into a fine mist and be send into orbit. The entire temperature of the planet would rise to over 5,000 degress Centigrade, hotter than the surface of the Sun and enough to melt Titanium at the moment of impact, and would still remain at over 1,000 Centigrades for days after due to all the hydrocarbon on the planet igniting. The 1% of bacteria that survived the immediate impact(100% of all multi-cellular organims and 99% of bacteria would be exterminated at the moment of impact), would be charcoaled by temperatures 10 X higher than the highest temperature life is known to live in. Yes, this would be an "absolute" extinction event with 100% of all members of 100% of all species ceasing to exist. We are talking about en energy here equivalent to a trillion trillion atomic bombs.

In fact, we have narrowed down the moment that abiogenesis happened between 4.28 billion yeara ago to 3.7 billion years ago. That is, from the impact of Theia on Earth(that formed the Moon) 4..28 billion years ago to the first inequivocal fossil 3.7 billion years ago. That is could not have happened before 4.28 billion years ago is because there is nothing that could sruvive that impact, not even bacteria living deep underneth the ground or in ancient vents.

You start out in one of three locations you can choose from:


A. The Big City - A more inland coastal city than others, highrise buildings, start off in an apartment with low funding and no occupation - [Normal Difficulty]

Benefits: Higher buildings means you can stay where you are for longer. Lots of places to pillage once things go bad thus plenty of food available if you play right
Consequences: Being in a city means lots of competition and high crime rate. Being in an apartment means for the first 4 weeks you will need to pay an ungodly horrible rent just to stay in your apartment (rent becomes irrelevant after 4 weeks as society starts to really crumble)
Way to get to safer place: You cannot afford a trip out of the city as you don't own a car and are barely surviving off of bits and scraps here and there. By the time rent is irrelevant, the city itself has already flooded and you have no money nor ability to purchase a boat as the banks have been flooded (I guess you could try to break into them). Power is shutting off at this point as the power grid becomes too unstable. In order to get to a safer place, you need to either get in a safety helicopter as they evacuate whoever they can to a refugee camp far, far inland or you can try to hitch a ride with an npc out of the place, both options have a limited time frame to actually be able to do.

Way to "win": Get into the limited time Refugee camp and convince others to help you go further inland with all of the important resources needed for a better encampment (easier to do if you come in with the helicopters). The more people you have with you, the more you would have to take care of but at the same time easier management of social need, higher strength, and quicker construction of various things vital for survival. You'd eventually want to either find a way to construct a bunker with enough resources to outlast the upcoming months of reckoning and help you support you and your people or you would need to find a hidden governmental bunker that is made to help keep humanity alive after the death of society. You could also go to a public bunker but crime rates might be high and there might not be enough space for you and your people


B. The Rural Landscape - Local residence inland with small amount of plants and animals, moderate funding and farming occupation, not too far from a river that eventually feeds into the ocean (it's quite a long river) and also nearby a local town separate from the rest of society- [ Hard difficulty]

Benefits: Away from the coast means longer survivability. Income and moderate savings
Consequences: In drought, meaning that farming would be more difficult. River will eventually flood and reach you. Shipments take the longest to get to you out of the three options. You need to manually drive your vehicle to the closest town to sell your goods. People don't know that the world is ending in your town until around 3 months when the moon is so big that people of the town start to notice (they don't go out at night too much)
Way to get to a safer place: Gather enough resources and money to abandon your place and move higher inland. You would loose your wide amount of farmland, would sell for only a small amount with the town (would have to be within the first week or two since the news would get widespread that the moon is going to crash into the earth and thus people will start to buy and move to any land that is away from the coasts to try and survive)

Way to "win": Unless you get god luck finding materials for a bunker and manage your resources incredibly intensively, you'd want to try and find a private bunker to get access to or a refugee bunker (a bunker that was either constructed by refugees or was stolen by refugees) or a public safety bunker designed for the public (last ditch attempt honestly)


C. The Coastal Suburbs - Coastal residence with high funding and high end occupation - [Easy Difficulty]

Benefits: You have a very good position to purchase things and get resources
Consequences: You are in a very flat area that extends for many kilometers. Near others so crime rate can increase as the days go by. Less than a month to get out of the suburbs before you are flooded
Way to get to a safer place: Selling your house and moving inland immediately will result in you loosing your job as you cannot reach it (any place outside of the city is out of your reach, for gameplay reasons). You would need to move in with someone else and wait until your job gives you the opportunity to "work from home" where you could then move out to your house far inland and still get paid while somewhere safe (your occupation is a national company that shifts over to online jobs as their bases of operation get destroyed, abandoned, or understaffed.)


I guess this is a game concept of mine, would be a first person game with gorgeous graphics ) for that sight you will see 60 real life days later when the moon crashes into the earth (1/6 that of a normal year and 6 real hour days instead of 24). Would need to manage food, water, money (will change once society collapses, becoming irrelevant when most of it is gone, only to come back as a replacement for trading once things settle and society starts to come back 120 days after the moon's descent, total of 180 real time days put into the game), and mental health (You would need to bring another person along with you to keep your social health sustainable, but barely).
Because you might be the leader for a group of people for a normal difficulty game, you could set in your own rules for managment of the people as your local population starts to grow either with new humans born or the occasional survivor. Essentially, you would want to keep them working together to stay alive.

In order to survive the extreme conditions, you would need to either construct or locate a bunker supplied with enough food, water, oxygen filters, and other protective measures to keep you alive as you waited out the toxic clouds and harsh temperature conditions.
You would expect the following after the moon disintegrates:
-Periods of unpredictable toxic clouds covering the sky to bright clearings of sunlight, would slowly diminish until around day 120 AMD (After Moon's descent) where you would have very rare, brief periods of acid rain and toxic clouds in your local area depending on where you settled
-Whatever items of the past world remain in your collection, these become priceless and can be used either for their abilities. Guns for intimidation/protect against whatever wildlife may or may not still exist, electronics for advanced calculations or circuitry to either automate processes or for more advanced builds, "artifacts" that can be used as priceless trading pawns, and books for knowledge of the BMD world (Before Moon's Descent) and for tools that could impact your survival by a major factor
-Extremely rare chance for survivor thieves to come and attack you, like we're talking 0.001 percent chance range
-Possibility to trade with other small tribes that managed to survive, would be very hard to contact them within the first 30 to 60 days.

Way to "win": Easiest method is to build up resources to then build a bunker with enough supplies for you to survive somewhere inland or perhaps even up closer to the poles.


Since it is likely that most plants and animals will perish, the seed vault would be the ultimate challenge to get to but might be the most rewarding. Not only would you need to trek across a ravaged hellscape or a desolate, frozen wasteland, but you would also need to bring enough resources to be able to survive your trip to Norway. Perhaps there would be an underground aeronautics facility somewhere out there that you could get into and use as a method to get to Norway. Maybe there still remains a functional Airplane somewhere out there.
Manual pollination would also be an issue if no other animals really exist to help pollinate, fertile land would also be an issue.

Overall, it would be the most intensive strategy survival game out there if it went exactly by these rules, having +1000 hours of gameplay just to get to the end of the world.

Interesting video.  Everyone expects the moon to slam into the earth whole and not break up and turn into a ring system.  The only thing that has an issue is the part where the Earth Gravity pulling objects off the moon when it gets close to the earth.  We have to remember that an Orbit is the same as falling.  In the moons perspective it and everything on it is falling to earth at the same speed, therefore objects or any astronauts on the moon can’t be pulled off its surface.  You can test this by dropping a basketball and a bowling ball at the same time indoors (baske ball can be influenced by wind). They would fall at the same time.  That is exactly what is happening to the moon and the objects on the moon.

I would love to see this (definitely great, don't get me wrong) video retitled and another video released that's ACTUALLY about the moon crashing to the earth, but I know that probably doesn't make sense for you to do, so I'm just a bit disappointed. In the late stage you said the moon is orbiting faster than the Earth... pulling the tide faster than Earth's spin but no, even before the slow down spell the moon's orbit is slower than Earth's spin.  The Earth's spin is actually imparted to the moon giving it more velocity over time while equally slowing down Earth's spin.  But the closer they get the more spin matching would occur at a faster rate, all the while it's the Earth imparting its rotational speed to the moon.

In celestial mechanics, the Roche limit, also called Roche radius, is the distance from a celestial body within which a second celestial body, held together only by its own force of gravity, will disintegrate because the first body's tidal forces exceed the second body's gravitational self-attraction.

Inside the Roche limit, orbiting material disperses and forms rings, whereas outside the limit, material tends to coalesce.

The Roche radius depends on the radius of the first body and on the ratio of the bodies' densities.

There would be no calendar system because a day on earth without a moon would be six to twelve hours. A year without a moon would have over 1000 days.

The ecosystem will be destroyed; predators will die of hunger, and insects will grow in number and eat crops. It would result in a food crisis all over the world. The marine life will be hit much harder because their survival depends on tides.

With the moon removed from the equation, there will be almost no tides, and oceans will become calm.

There will be no moonlight, and nights will turn much darker, and there will be no more romantic moonlight walks. The Earth core will feel the change, and volcanic activities and earthquakes will become frequent. The ocean water may spread across the earth and reduce the tidal friction.

The moon makes the earth habitable, and without the moon, the life on earth as we know it would not exist.

The correct title for this video should be more like 'What Happens if the Moon Slows Down'. To properly 'simulate' the moon crashing into the Earth, you would need just that; the moon crashing into the Earth. This would require a giant object passing through our Solar System (so it is not in orbit around our sun like the other planets) that either changes the moons orbit or simply hits the moon like a billiard ball into the Earth; though that would likely then be some merged moon/dwarf planet something somehow knocks the moon into the Earth (which I assume would be something similar to a giant giant meteor striking the Earth). In the scenario portrayed, the moon merely breaks up and only a small amount of moon ever 'crashes' into the Earth.

Instead we luckily have this unlikely but perfect object to holding our seasons, responsible for life as we know it. Without our near constant 23 degree tilt the Earth would swing from 0 to 90 degrees with very little stability instead of our miracle life providing moon.

It would probably affect the economy

The moon is moving away from the earth, as the moon is slowly gaining energy from the earths rotation that lifts its orbit higher. That is why the earths days are getting longer. The moon started out at around 20 thousand miles away from earth, and is now around 238 thousand miles away (yes, the early earth would have had kilometer high tides every few
hours if there was liquid water at the time). Eventually the earth's rotation will slow down enough that it will become tide locked to the moon, as the the moon is now tide locked to the earth. Tide locked is when one face of an orbiting body, or a body being orbited, always points to the other body.

Once the earth is tide locked to the moon, and has one side that always faces the moon, the moon will no longer be able to gain energy from earths rotation, and its orbit will begin to decay. It will begin to do what this video projects, except it will be millions of years in the future. It will also be after the sun has become a red giant, and the earth and moon will be inside of the sun's surface, so we do not know if they will even survive that process, let alone last long enough to allow the moon to become a ring around earth.

This is interesting, but to me the premise seems completely and rather bizarrely arbitrary, rendering this little more than an interesting thought experiment.

The whole premise of this scenario is odd because it seems to posit that the only way the moon could ever crash into the earth is by literal magic, and that the most sensible way that magic would be applied is in the form of a slow, gradual force applied constantly over the period of a year. This is bizarre because there is no realistic condition under which this would ever happen, except by, as they say, magic.

On the contrary, it's completely possible for the moon's orbit to be perturbed enough to put it on a collision course with Earth, though it would obviously involve some dramatic interaction with a sufficiently large celestial body, or numerous large asteroid impacts in a short period of time. If a sufficiently large celestial object got close enough to the moon, it could dramatically slow or change the trajectory of the moon's orbit around Earth. If its orbit was disturbed enough, this could lower the periapsis of the moon's orbit enough to put the moon on a direct collision course with Earth. Similarly, several large asteroid impacts hitting the moon directly opposite its prograde heading (large enough to slow the moon without destroying it) could produce a similar effect.

Is the above scenario likely? Of course not. But in contrast to the scenario Kurzgesagt presents, it is at least theoretically possible, and doesn't require magic.

In any case, if the moon's orbit was perturbed enough to stop it dead in its tracks, it would indeed "fall from the sky" on a direct collision course to Earth. There wouldn't be anything gradual about it. It would likely fall to earth within a few weeks and would not hang out in low Earth orbit long enough to break up into tiny pieces. It would instead slam directly into Earth, likely causing a mass-extinction-level disaster.

I find it odd that Kurzgesagt presents their scenario basically saying "If this could happen, here's how it would happen," when their scenario makes no sense and simultaneously ignores the ways in which this could theoretically actually happen in reality.

A few minor nitpicking issues

First off an object falling within the Roche limit would only fall apart that quickly if it was entirely held together by gravity which since the Moon is a differentiated body which has cooled outside of hydrostatic equilibrium is something we know is not the case thus it would likely take millennia or longer for the Moon to fully fall apart with the lunar core likely remaining intact since iron cores can survive far more extreme tidal forces than Earth or even the Sun can provide. That ultimately probably means kilometer+ scale chunks of Moon falling down to the Earth over millennia in nasty impacts which while slow for an astrophysical impact would be highly destructive because of how huge and numerous the pieces would be. After all all the asteroids combined amount to no more than 4% the mass of the Moon meaning that is a lot of mass to fall back down to Earth.

One problem with ring systems is that ring systems are ephemeral as the ring particles regularly collide pushing the bulk of the material to spiral inwards in this case that means falling into the Earth or they are pushed outside the Roche limit and begin to reaccrete into new smaller moons as is occurring around Saturn today.

Thanks to the data collected from the Cassini mission the moons Mimas, Enceladus Tethys Dione Rhea and Titan as well as the numerous dynamically unstable smaller moons and accreting ring moonlets are all believed to have formed from ring material after the cataclysm that formed the rings of Saturn occurred some billion years ago and the rings at the current rates of material loss will likely be gone 100 million years from now leaving only a thin fossil ring. Also the net effects of an infalling ring system and tidal interactions with it would be substantial the process which is ongoing around Saturn has been increasing in obliquity driving the giant planet from equatorial low inclination to its high and increasing inclination. If ring formation effects can do that to Saturn they could and likely would tip Earth over onto its side completely which isn't surprising as our models suggest the proto Earth Theia impact is what set the Earth's axial tilt and Earth Moon orbital plane inclinations.

I feel like this video was a cop out of the original question. You didn't explain why the earth's orbital decay slows down exponentially as it gets closer. Sure, it's orbit will speed up as it draws near, but gravity will also pull it in faster as well.

We have decades of satellite and rocket debris to model orbital decay, and spoiler: slow moving objects fall out of orbit and hit the earth all the time, especially as earth's atmosphere creates drag in LEO. The earth also doesn't have the same gravitational pull as a gas giant, so rather than breaking apart into dust, the moon would just hit us, perhaps after breaking apart into chunks. This video seems to suggest that it's impossible for a moon-size object to hit the earth, because it would instead turn into dust rings.

Admittedly, I am too lazy to do the math, but the thumbnail image is more likely than the video, where the moon turns completely into dust and settles into LEO. I skimmed through your bonus reading material, and didn't see anything about the orbital decay math that led to the outcome in the video. With that said, I still enjoyed it, and always look forward to your videos.

Gravity doesn't take the moon anywhere.  By changing the energy in the moon's relative motion, the curve of spacetime that the moon is sliding along changes though, as the Earth's mass' influence on spacetime becomes more obvious on the moon's mass.  Gravity is not a force.  It's a name we apply to the phenomenon of mass changing the way spacetime curves and in turn changes where other masses move because Einstein's "gravity" is hard to get your head around.

Hi Kurzgesagt, I am not exactly sure what you mean by "according to science". This gives the notion that science is some kind of centralised knowledge institution, which it is not. The scientific method is merely a tool on how to deal with questions, it should not be used as an authority argument, even in a harmless situation like this. Using the word science in such a manner, gives rise to the possibility of moralising and politicising scientific data, which should be avoided at all costs to preserve the integrity of the method.

Erm... the Roche Limit is the distance at which Earth's gravity overcomes self gravity, but not necessarily other internal forces. Long term, yes, decaying moons grind themselves into meter scale objects and eventually dust, but short term, there will VERY large impactors. It unlikely atmospheric drag would be significant at 10-20 Mm, especially for anything of significant mass, but inter-ring collisions and conservation of angular momentum would eject significant material outward and inward. Much of that material has structural strength beyond self-gravitation. boulders are held together by more than just gravity. mountain sized bolides may fracture before hitting the surface, but not enough to prevent them from delivering their full kinetic energy. impact velocities would be significantly less than comets or even asteroids, but depending on the amount of material that makes it to the Earth's surface and the rate of impact, there would be significant surface disruption, if not outright glassing significant percentages of the Earth's equatorial surface under the moon/rings orbital plane.
The moon has a terrifying amount of mechanical energy, Even magic'd down to the Roche Limit with the prerequisite reduction of orbital velocity. Its hard to estimate how long such a ring would last. Saturn's ring may have a half billion year life span, but it's orbit is significant further out than Earth's Roche limit. If we applied the same lifespan to such a lunar ring assumed a significant amount of mass was ejected away from the earth, we're still looking at millions of kgs of material per second averaged over that time (average being far too conservative at it's worst, as it would follow a logistic curve rather than linear). For context, 10 seconds at that rate would equate to a year of Earth's normal rate of mass gain from everything from impacts to interstellar dust.

Fun fact: currently, the Moon's gravitational pull/tidal forces cause the crust of the Earth to rise up to about a foot, or ~0.3 meters, during high tide. But that's so insignificantly tiny compared to the huge size of the Earth that it's not even close to being noticeable,or to have any significant effect (maybe in some places it does affect volcanic activity, or plate tectonics, not sure) .
And, of course, there are also atmospheric tides, which can have significant effects on the weather.

Once thing to mention too is that we would need to slow the Moon's velocity relative to the Earth and tangent to it's orbit. Not mentioning this, you could be slowing it relative to the sun, the solar system (same thing), or to the galactic center (!!!) which would mean the moon goes away from us.

1:08 I disagree with this explanation, its simplistic but I don't think it accurately represents gravity.

Gravity always pulls towards the center of the earth, no matter how fast you move you cant change that. Saying it falls sideways means it'll just hit the ground at a very fast sideways speed, that is assuming gravity is the only force acting on the object, which isn't entirely true.

Although it is an imaginary force, you need to conciser centripetal force, as gravity pulls the object in, because its moving sideways in a circular motion it ends up being flung back out with equal force to gravity, which allows it to stay afloat.

Sort of like swinging around a ball on a rope. Say you were able to continuously pull the rope inwards with the same force, like gravity, move the ball too slow and centripetal force isn't strong enough to equal your pulling force and it comes back towards you, like throwing a ball from the ground. Swing it too hard and the centripetal force is stronger than your pulling force and you lose the ball, like an elliptical orbit or an escape trajectory. if you go the exact speed that matches up with your pulling force you achieve a circular orbit.

I don't think a month is long enough for the moon to completely break up. Comet Shoemaker-Levy 9 passed through Jupiter's Roche limit dozens of times, with a perijove of 40,000km and apojove of 50,000,000km, over a 30+ year period and had only been broken up into 21 pieces. Shoemaker-Levy 9's orbit was super eccentric, while the moon's in this example is roughly spherical, so the total time spent in the Roche limit is probably greater, but I don't think it would end up as rings, if the force decelerating the moon kept being applied to the largest piece, it would still be several hundred km in diameter, moving at 8km/s by the end of the year.

2:35 I think it's worth mentioning that the moon is not solely responsible for Earth's tides. The sun's gravity accounts for the majority of the water movement. The Moon's gravity is great enough to give the tides a little nudge in either direction and this is the reason why high and low tides are tied to the phases of the Moon. If the Earth didn't have a singular large moon, we would still have tides, but they would more or less have the same amount of intensity day to day and would just ebb and flow with Earth's rotation

Okay, I don't understand why objects on the Moon would get pulled off the surface of the Moon once the Moon passes the Roche Limit.  Yes, the pull of gravity from the Earth surpasses the pull of gravity from the Moon, but the Moon and the Earth are still attracting each other, so wouldn't the Moon get pulled closer to the Earth just as much as an object on its surface would , thereby keeping it on its surface?  Put another way, if you drop a bowling ball and an apple from a tall building at the same time, they will hit the ground at the same time (disregarding air resistance).  The mass of the objects doesn't matter.  So wouldn't the same thing happen with the Moon and an object on its surface?  Or does the fact that the Moon and the object aren't falling straight down change things somehow?

9:44 Wouldn't this not be friction, and instead be air compression?

I assume that they are talking about re-entry types of heat from the previous quote "if a lot of moon dust begins to fall down to Earth,"

Air compression is the phenomena that causes all that re-entry heat and plasma. In laymans terms, it's because the gas in the atmosphere doesn't have enough time to move from the path of the object, causing it to heat rapidly into a plasma state.

The best thing is, we might actually have more mass on the rings in such a small surface area. The rings on Saturn are estimated to be around 40% the mass of Mimas, and Mimas is both smaller and less massive than The Moon, having at least 2000 times less mass. And because Saturn is obviously a big planet, the rings stretch out so much, so if it's on Earth, it would probably be much, much brighter, and have much more material

What I'm saying is, if the Moon does become a ring, it might be far more beautiful and impressive than Saturn's own

The breakup of the Moon (formation of rings) doesn't make sense. Gravity wouldn't pull the Moon apart. It would just pull the whole Moon towards the Earth. Otherwise, gravity would pull everything apart, including people or anything else really.

The idea of the Roche limit is just a theoretical attempt to explain rings, but gravity doesn't tear things apart, obviously. Even over a vast difference of distance, from one side of the Moon to the other, there's no way it would cause the Moon to disintegrate. It would require many other forces at work.

There's just no evidence to suggest that gravity tears things apart like that. Rings actually suggest that rotation began to happen before the planet fully coalesced. Causing gravitational rotation, or orbit.

May be it was lost in translation, but the Moon has a lot of benefits for the stability and climate (yeah, I know) of earth. Even the earth spin on its axis gets "stabilized" by having (a relatively big) moon (if it wasn't for the moon, the earth would tend to wobble more, making for bigger changes on different places whether and what not). And that is the tip of the iceberg.

Losing all that and earth soon enough would transform into another different planetary entity and not precisely for the better. Our planet is a (metaphorically) miracle of accumulation of pro-life circumstances that we take for granted, so much so that we tend to ignore many of them when "inventing" (on Sfi Fi fantasies) other friendly-to-life planets.

What If The Moon Crashed Into Earth? If the Moon fell into the Earth the collision would break the Earth immediately into large chunks as it joined with and merged with the moon. The magma released would cause a firestorm that would engulf the Earth extinguishing all life, boil the oceans and change the angle of our axis changing the spin.

As it is, the moon moves away from the earth about a 1-1/2” per year.  So 65 million years ago with the dinosaurs, the moon would have been a lot closer.  The effect of the moon on the earth would have been more.  Would have had more of a effect on the environment overall.

A more likely scenario would be something like a rogue planet or something else of exceptional mass disturbing the orbit, yanking on the Moon (and also the Earth to a lesser extent) into a more elliptical orbit. The Moon is already in an elliptical orbit fluctuating between 363,200 km and 405,400 km from Earth, the lesser of which is what we currently refer to as a "Supermoon". This would cause some high tides and low tides to be much more of an extreme then they are now. The real issue is that as the perigee (the closest part in orbit) could drag on the atmosphere or interact in various want to cause it to get closer and closer, until a potentially violent intersection.

Fundamentally the reason the moon does not crash into earth is due to the fact the earth is not stationary, quite the opposite the earth is moving thousands of kilometers towards the sun, the reason the earth does not crash into the sun is because the sun itself is moving thousands of kilometers away from earth. Such in that creates a equilibrium that a force of large gravitational attraction eventually leading the center of the universe, leads to perpetual motion, and orbit. If the earth was in fact stationary with no other gravitational forces acting on it, yes the moon and earth would indeed crash together. I surprised you did not mention this, as it is extremely basic physics.

I think I'm gonna have to disagree. If the roche limit was that high up most asteroids would be shredded before impacting the earth and satellites would need to be FAR more dense and reinforced. I remember doing this math myself in a 2nd year uni astronomy course and the roche limit for rock is closer to 1/3rd of the way into the crust. I can agree that that size of orbiting planetoid would be partially deconstructed but not so far as it would create a homogeneous ring, remember that the moon did form from that but it wouldn't be so easily reverted, after all we were hit by a planet about 1/3rd the size of earth which warped the gravitational geometry a bit which is why we technically had a ring-like structure before it amalgamated into the moon. Also, even if that happened, the momentum of the moon's decent would still swing the debris into the earth.

As a real world example of my point, Mar's moons are both far closer and of similar density to our moons but they are not rings. A gas giant is the only thing with enough mass to create a roche limit outside of it's surface gravity to create that kind of ring unfortunately

"But there is no other force countering gravity"
Yes and no. From Earth's frame of reference, the moon has a velocity tangent to its orbit, the acceleration due to gravity caused by the Earth is exactly enough to make the velocity stay tangent at its current orbit. From the moon's rotating frame of reference, it is at equilibrium, the force due to gravity is counteracted by a centrifugal force.

Very accurate however one thing I might add is also the mass of earth changing making it's gravity slightly stronger. Survivors may never be able to leave earth again. You have to consider that the moon plays a roll in rocket launches. NASA generally likes to launch on days where the moon is in visible orbit during the day time. That ever so slight pull helps rockets reach space and it also keeps most of our satellites in orbit. Without it their orbit would decay and fall back to earth. The ISS would be toast for this reason. Also the tides would stop meaning the ocean would be put into a very slow spin. This means that the salinity of the ocean would change killing most sea life and creating stagnant pools where PH would greatly fluctuate. Coral reef life would become basically extinct.

Sorry but I need to say that your explaination for the tides is wrong.
You use the newtonian static model and it does not work in reality (tides will be in cm and not in m acording to this model).
And the tides are never directly below the moon. The high tide arrive hours after the moon is above one place.
You need to use the dynamic laplacian model if you want to correctly understand and explain the tides.

This was drivel. But you did get one thing correct...were the moon to survive intact for long enough, there is a point at which Earths gravitational attraction could outweigh ( pun...get it? Nope. Didn't think so.) that of the moon. But it would be dust rock and general debris that would casacade seemingly at first. What is most likely true is that differentials in gravtational forces would cause sheer fractures long before 10k km. Those forces would break large chunks off the moon. Those chunks...not one, but many...would likely be the size of the object that hit Earth 65 million years ago. So, several exitinction level events would occur prior to the final event when a fairly sizeable portion of the moon would collide and create an event of such a scale that the entire crust of the Earth would be liquified and the atmosphere burned up.

I don't know where your assessment came from but it is woefully inaccurate....oh, it was a wiki...now I get it. As a point, the reason that some planets have rings is because the objects that made the rings disintegrated ( the technical use of the term...to break apart or dis - integrate) far from the planet surface. This is due to the mass disparity between the two objects and the composition of the impactor. Hence Saturns rings are largely domintated by ice rather than rock. Icy comets break up easily. Large asteroids or planetoids like ceres do not. The latter cleave into mountains of rock. Those mountains find there way to the planets surface. The moon is fairly large compared to Earth. All those forces are going to cause the Moon to break up but it would not shatter into a billion little fragments. Further, all those big pieces that survive will all fall back inevitably. The interaction between pieces and their extreme proximity to Earth guarantees that they will rain down the final phase of destruction of whatever piece of crust remains.

There's a significant issue in the script of this video:
"...so we'll use a magic spell that slows down the Moon so much that it changes its orbit and spirals towards Earth."

This sentence implies the following process:
1. The Moon is slowed down.
2. The Moon spirals towards Earth.

This process is not realistic. And considering that the spiralling motion was predicted by Matthew Caplan, Doctor of Physics, I doubt that this is the process that was used either. Much more likely is that the Moon in this video is slowing down gradually. That would in fact result in a spiralling approach.

In short, the video could do with a more precise explanation of the exact magic being used.

This is all wrong...  The rise of tides is not directly proportional to the distance of the moon... You've got to factor in the limit of total water quantity.  There is a point at which the moon's effect on tide becomes saturated.  Once that threshold is reached there can be no more rise of tide.  Even if the moon totally disintegrates once it reaches the orbit belt beneath geostationary satellite positions, the total mass concentration of the earth will also have shifted, likely causing the earth's orbit around the sun to decay slightly...  This would increase the earth's surface temperature likely beyond a point tolerable by human life.  If the human race doesn't first destroy itself by its own actions, it will still not survive the number of years it would take for the ACTUAL decay of the moon's orbit, not this BS 1-year timeline proposed.  The temperature rise alone, during this slow decay process, will wipe us out, along with so many other variables that are not being factored in here.... This is really totally junk science, and should be completely disregarded, even as conjecture.  The fact is that we are on an inevitable path to destruction, and there isn't anything we can do about it. The actual decay of planetary orbits won't happen for billions of  years, but we'll be long gone before it happens.

Even if some humans did survive the initial event, extinction would be inevitable because the planet would be effectively dead.
Without the moon's gravitational influence Earth's molten core would cool and all geological activity would cease. No geological activity means no tectonic plate movement. No tectonic plate movement means no minerals being pumped up from oceanic vents. No minerals means there will be nothing to feed microscopic lifeforms. The food chain would collapse.

Worse still Earth's molten iron core is what generates our magnetic field. Without it the planet would be blasted with radiation from the sun and much of our atmosphere would evaporate into space. In a couple of hundred thousand years Earth would be nothing more than a barren rock.

I guess Humankind would never rebuild civilization. The Moon is the only reason we have something like "civilization" on earth. Without the stabilizing forces of the Monn something like agriculture wouldn't work, because there are no reliable seasons without the Moon. The temperatures fluctuate between 50°C in the summer in Europe/USA and -50°C in the winter. And this can basically happen over night - or never, Plants would have basically 0 time to adapt to that change and can't grow. Days would be about  8 hours long, nights only about 2 hours and 40 minutes. We would have storms traveling around the earth with about 500km/h. Not even mentioning what would happen in the sea...
